homeHeader: Immerse yourself in the romantic wilderness of the Scottish Highlands in luxurious self-catered holiday properties and Bed and Breakfast accommodation.ssss
topSectionHeaderID4557: Well-appointed, unique, pet-friendly holiday cottages on the West Coast of Scotland.
centerTextID4557:
Daydreaming about your next holiday?

At Kingairloch we have ten delightful self-catering properties located throughout 14,000 acres on the Morvern Peninsula, allowing guests to enjoy utter peace and quiet in accessible isolation.

Every property has it’s own character, all have fantastic views of either the mountains, lochs or rivers. Open all year round with weekly lets from a Friday and Saturday and short breaks from either a Monday or a Friday.

Pets are also welcomed.
bottomSectionReviewsContent:
UpFront Reviews is a verified review service for rental accommodation that uses the SuperControl Online Booking System to ensure that reviews are left only by genuine past guests. It enables the property owner/manager to receive valuable feedback about their accommodation, and visitors to view real reviews before they stay.

The reviews you see on UpFront Reviews can only be submitted by people who have actually stayed in that property. This means you can trust that UpFront Reviews is used by real people who agree to share their guest experience with you. The reviews are genuine and verified – perfect to help you plan your next stay.

UpFront Reviews exclusively lists self-catering properties that use SuperControl online booking system as we use the system to verify reviews.

rollOverBoxes.rollOverBoxContent: Riverside Cottage sits above the banks of the River Coinnich, with views from the rear of the house taking in the glens and mountains that surround the property.
The enchanting lodge to Kingairloch House, this property has one of the finest views on the estate and is unique by being constructed from cut granite.
The Old Post Office is a beautiful stone cottage sitting above the shore of Loch a’Choire. In front of the cottage is a large lawn area where deer are often seen grazing.
If it is utter seclusion you are looking for, then Seaview Cottage is perfect for you. This delightful stone built cottage is accessible along a winding estate track skirting the loch’s edge.
The Steadings has been imaginatively renovated from a former derelict barn to a stylish and beautifully presented house with stunning views across lush grassland to the sea…
Elastic Cottage is a fabulous single storey stone cottage that sits within the hamlet of Camasnacroise, a picturesque bay that opens out onto Loch Linnhe.
Pier Cottage is a beautiful stone cottage located right on the edge of the loch; a wonderful compact cottage for a getaway break, or an ideal base to explore…
Located on the Camus na Croise bay; this cottage sits in a prime location, with quite simply some of the best views available on the West Coast of Scotland.
Encompassed by mountains and glens, this stone cottage sits in an elevated position on the estate with fantastic views from all aspects.
On entering Kingairloch via the scenic single track road that skirts along the edge of Loch Linnhe, Curlew Cottage is one of the first properties on the estate.

topSectionHeader_ID4557: Well appointed, unique, pet friendly holiday cottages on the West Coast of Scotland.
topSectionHeader_ID4580: Large, pet friendly well appointed holiday cottage with mountainous views.

Riverside Cottage

£520-880 per week | 100% Recommended by guests

A Luxurious, characterful family friendly cottage

Riverside Cottage sits above the banks of the River Coinnich, with views from the rear of the house taking in the glens and mountains that surround the property.

Tastefully renovated from a formerly derelict building, it has all of the comforts that provide a ‘home from home’ destination for the duration of your stay.

The interior designed property is furnished with ANTA fabrics to the highest standard. Downstairs there is an open plan sitting room and dining room with a wood burning stove for cosy evenings by the fire. The centrepiece of the kitchen is an electric two-oven Aga, providing the cooking as well as additional warmth for those colder days.

There is also a utility room with a washing machine and tumble dryer. The downstairs rooms benefit from under floor heating throughout. Three upstairs bedrooms are complimented with a shower room, en-suite to the master bedroom, and a bathroom downstairs; including a period cast iron bath big enough for the whole family!

The rear outdoor patio area has been enjoyed by many families over the years and is a wonderful place to take in the mountains whilst listening to the burbling river below. The estate’s productive walled garden is a stone’s throw from the house and guests are more than welcome to visit the garden.

Up to three dogs welcome, charged at £24/pet. Partially fenced garden/gravel/patio grass area.

topSectionHeader_ID4641: Converted barn with en-suite rooms for larger groups surrounded by mountains.

The Steadings

£1325-£1700 | 100% Recommended by guests

A beautifully furnished home for larger groups visiting the Highlands

The Steadings has been imaginatively renovated from a former derelict barn to a stylish and beautifully presented house with stunning views across lush grassland to the sea and the island of Lismore beyond. Situated at the entrance to Glengalmadale, the backdrop to this property is spectacular. The Loch Linnhe shoreline is a short walk from the cottage where there is a delightful stone beach to watch the waves roll in.

Attractively furnished and well equipped throughout with a bright, fresh feel that encourages relaxation, this single storey house provides an ideal family venue and caters for all ages and abilities. The large, stylish open plan kitchen, lounge and dining room opens onto the conservatory; creating the heart of the house and is a marvellous gathering place after exhilarating days spent out and about. All bedrooms are en suite and are equipped with TVs in each room. There is also an additional shower/wet room that is wheelchair friendly. Outside a pretty sun-trap courtyard is ideal for summertime barbeques. There is also a useful bike store and a small enclosed garden.

We can only accept group bookings for 2021 from two house holds for the time being. This is limited to six people, however children under 12 are not included in the head count. For bookings in 2022 we hope this rule will be relaxed. A low occupancy discount is calculated for groups who only require up to three bedrooms.

If you have any queries about booking, please email us.

Up to three dogs welcome, charged at £24/pet. Fenced garden/grass area.

topSectionHeader_ID4643: Family sized pet friendly holiday cottage set on the shoreline of Loch Linnhe.

Elastic Cottage

£460-775 per week | 100% Recommended by guests

A charming cosy cottage on the shore of Loch Linnhe

Elastic Cottage is a fabulous single storey stone cottage that sits within the hamlet of Camasnacroise, a picturesque bay that opens out onto Loch Linnhe. Simply one of the finest locations in the West Highlands!

The cottage sleeps up to four in a double and twin bedroom, both of which look out to Loch Linnhe. The living, dining and kitchen area is open plan with the wood burning stove being a great feature in the room. There is a shared family bathroom with a bath and overhead shower unit. Further to this, a fantastic wooden deck sits prominently in the enclosed garden – the perfect place to watch the sun rise and set over the Appin Hills and Castle Stalker.

There are lots of walks and sights to enjoy right from the doorstep of this cottage. When the tide is out, ambling along the beach always presents a treasure-trove of delights and the magnificent Glengalmadale (opposite image) is only a five minute walk away.

Spotting red deer at Kingairloch is always high on the list for our visitors. However, this video is a real delight as it shows them swimming in the river in front of The Old School and Elastic Cottage.

topSectionHeader_ID4645: Luxurious well appointed holiday cottage on the loch’s edge, a nature lover’s paradise.

Pier Cottage

£440-725 per week | 100% Recommended by guests

A newly renovated stone cottage on the shore of Loch a’Choire

Pier Cottage is located right on the edge of the loch; a wonderful cottage for a getaway break, or an ideal base to explore Kingairloch and the surrounding areas.

After undergoing a major refurbishment, this cottage is now oozing charm, character and comfort. The cottage is as exceptional as the setting; a beautiful mix of a traditional stone cottage with the addition of a timber clad sunroom.

Entering the cottage you find a smart and stylish kitchen and dining area with the en-suite bedroom and sunroom located at either end of the cottage. The entire space has been beautifully designed, finished and furnished to the highest possible standards, giving guests a real sense of luxury.

In the sunroom, the views of Loch a’Choire are spectacular and when the nights draw in, the wood burning stove adds an additional level of cosiness. Guests will find the welcome books and visitor information here helping you make the most of your time at Kingairloch and the surrounding area.

The ensuite bedroom has a lovely view of the loch and mountains and is furnished with a kingsize double bed with quirky nautical details adding to the character. The bathroom has a walk in shower.

Outside the cottage there is comfortable outdoor seating. There is also ample parking.

Up to two dogs are welcome (charged at £24/pet). Please note there is no fenced area and the private estate road does pass in front of the cottage, however traffic is minimal.

cottageIcons_ID4645.similarPropertiesContent_ID4645: Electric oven and hob, microwave, 50/50 tall fridge freezer
TV in lounge with DVD player. Wi-fi is available at The Boathouse
Pine martens, otters and red deer

topSectionHeader_ID4647: Large well-appointed family sized holiday property set on the shoreline of Loch Linnhe.

The Old School

£525-895 per week | 100% Recommended by guests

Luxurious, easily accessible, family friendly cottage set on the shore of Loch Linnhe

Located on the Camus na Croise bay; this cottage sits in a prime location, with quite simply some of the best views available on the West Coast of Scotland.

The meandering scenic single track road that brings you to Kingairloch forks down to the bay where this cottage is situated, you will find a large parking area and an enclosed garden to welcome you. It’s easy to see on arrival that The Old School is designed to make the best of its location, with large windows framing the spectacular views over the loch and surrounding hills.

The rear entrance takes you through the utility room which opens onto the spacious open plan kitchen, dining and living area. All on one level, the bedrooms and bathrooms are located a few steps away. Through the front door is a patio area with outdoor furniture and the garden is also fenced.

The living space is the real hub of this superb family home; a magnificent antler chandelier hangs from the double height ceiling in the lounge area and there is a wood burning stove that provides a wonderful focal point. Guests will enjoy the ever-changing visual display from Mother Nature depending on what mood the sea and weather present.

The kitchen is of a very high specification with quality appliances and an excellent range of cookware. This makes it a pleasure to prepare a meal in and with the open plan layout, you are always part of the party.

The master bedroom, is a spacious room with lovely views, abundant storage and beautiful art on the walls. Two atmospheric Jolomo paintings hang on the walls. A door leads to the large en-suite bathroom with a bath and separate shower.

The twin room is also beautifully decorated and has storage space. A separate shower room is located next to this bedroom.

Guests staying at The Old School will appreciate the warmth and light of this modern holiday house, and its breath-taking location, which make it an excellent base for exploring all areas of our part of the world.

Up to three pets are welcome and are charged at £24 each.

topSectionHeader_ID4649: Family sized holiday cottage surrounded by mountains; red deer are regular visitors.

Ghardail Cottage

£440-750 per week | 100% Recommended by guests

A charming remote cottage set in the magnificent hills of Kingairloch

Encompassed by mountains and glens, this remote stone cottage sits in an elevated position on the estate with fantastic views from all aspects. A short walk from the cottage is the River Ghardail, Loch Uisge plus our network of well signed footpaths. This is a wonderful base for guests wanting to explore the hills of Kingairloch and see a wide range of wildlife.

On entering the cottage through the side door, you are met with an open plan lay-out kitchen and living room. The kitchen is at the rear of the cottage, with windows looking out to a wooded hillside where deer are often seen grazing.

Going through to the living room there are comfortable sofas and a wood burning stove; with the stove lit the room becomes your own cosy Highland haven.

The double bedroom is downstairs with a view looking out to the hills of the estate. In the large bathroom you will find both a stand alone shower and bath.

Upstairs there is a twin room, please note it does have limited headroom.

Vehicles are able to park right next to the cottage.

There is a fenced area to the back of the cottage (currently not shown in photographs).

cottageIcons_ID4649.similarPropertiesContent_ID4649: Wood burning stove: Fuel can be bought from Kingairloch. Please do not use coal.
Electric oven, microwave, under counter fridge
TV with DVD player. Good EE 4G signal.

topSectionHeader_ID4654: Well-appointed family sized holiday cottage with loch and mountainous views.

Curlew Cottage

£480-830 | 100% recommended by guests

Perfect for families who love the Highlands

On entering Kingairloch via the scenic single track road that skirts along the edge of Loch Linnhe, Curlew Cottage is one of the first properties on the estate. With incredible views from both aspects, this is a great base for families to relax, unwind and explore the Highlands. The light and spacious kitchen and dining area have views of Loch Linnhe and the awe inspiring Glengalmadale horseshoe ridge of hills. The living room area has large comfortable sofas and the all important wood burning stove for creating a cosy atmosphere on holiday. All of the bedrooms lead off the living area, the master en-suite bedroom has a super-king size zip and link bed and enjoys views looking towards the magnificent Creach Bheinn, the highest point on the Morvern Peninsula. The second double is a king, with views towards Loch Linnhe. The third bedroom is a single and looks towards the Kingairloch hills. If guests require the super-king to be split into two twin beds, please let us know. There is also an additional separate shower room.

Up to three dogs are welcome (charged at £24 each), there is a small fenced area to the rear of the cottage.

There are lots of walks and sights to enjoy right from the doorstep of this cottage. A short stroll away and you are on the pebble beach listening to the waves from Loch Linnhe and the calls of seabirds including the Curlew, Oyster Catcher, Snipe and many more. The walk through Glengalmadale always takes your breath away; the shear size of the hills around you is spellbinding. Gazing to the skies Eagles are often seen and on the hillside, look out for grazing red deer and wild goats.

topSectionHeader_ID4635: Family sized luxurious holiday property encompassed by mountains and a lochside frontage.

The Gate Lodge

£520-880 per week | 100% Recommended by guests

A wonderful well-appointed lochside home with far reaching views

The enchanting lodge to Kingairloch House, this property has one of the finest views on the estate and is unique by being constructed from cut granite. Positioned at the head of Loch a’Choire; Castle Stalker, the Argyllshire hills and the glens and hills of Kingairloch can be enjoyed from all aspects.

Downstairs the house comprises of a large lounge and kitchen, both with stunning views of Loch Linnhe. The lounge has a large wood-burning stove and comfortable sofas. Additionally, there is a large utility room and downstairs shower room. Upstairs there are two large bedrooms (one double, one twin) with loch views and a large bathroom with a bath and separate shower. The bathroom is adjoined to the double bedroom, however there is another door for shared access for guests in the twin room. The house is fenced in traditional iron railings and has a patio area with outdoor furniture.

Up to three dogs welcome, charged at £24/pet. Iron railing fenced garden and outdoor kennels.

topSectionHeader_ID4637: Cosy holiday cottage with views of the loch and mountains; pine martens are regular visitors.

The Old Post Office

£440-725 per week | 100% Recommended by guests

The cottage is set back on a small hill from the private estate single track road that leads into the heart of Kingairloch. Past the lawn area, you can enjoy the sights and sounds of the tide as it rises and falls from the front of the cottage. There is ample parking at the cottage, which is laid to gravel.

Stepping inside the cottage, the sunroom is bright and welcoming with views down to the loch and the surrounding hills. There is comfortable seating, a wood burning stove, reading material and a television and DVD player.

The well equipped kitchen and dining area adjoins the sunroom. The modern bathroom with a bath and overhead shower is off the corridor that then leads down to the bedroom. Lying in bed, you can see the loch from the bedroom window. A perfect spot for breakfast in bed!

The sea air and mountainous scenery make this a great place for a relaxing holiday. Outside the cottage the view is constantly changing and artists, writers, photographers and wildlife enthusiasts will not be short of things to do. Stags are often seen grazing on the lawn area and at nightfall Pine Martens are regular visitors.

Up to three dogs are welcome, charged at £24/pet. Please note the garden area is not fenced.

topSectionHeader_ID4639: Romantic, remote holiday cottage set on the loch’s edge. Uninterrupted peace and quiet.

Seaview Cottage

£440-725 per week | 100% Recommended by guests

Located right on the loch’s edge and at the foot of some of Kingairloch’s most magnificent mountains, it’s best to pack your hiking boots and wellies as there’s lots of exploring to be had. Snug and comfortable, the cottage comprises of a lounge/kitchen area with log burning stove, a large bathroom with a bath and a separate shower and a generous bedroom. Outside there is a large bike store with supplies of firewood to see you through your stay.

Up to three dogs are also welcome, charged at £24 each. No fenced area.

The final stage to the cottage involves driving on an estate track and includes crossing a ford which is usually dry. Most vehicles will be able to reach the cottage, however if you are worried, we are able to take your luggage and shopping to and from the cottage in one of our 4x4s.

The adjacent image shows the new ford crossing.

Due to the upgraded track, the cottage is now open all year.

topSectionHeader_ID4559: Highland hospitality at its best; a luxurious B&B with views of Loch Linnhe and dramatic mountains.
centerTextID4559:
Luxurious and welcoming Bed and Breakfast on the Morvern Peninsula.

If you are looking for Bed and Breakfast on the West Coast of Scotland, few properties would be able to compete with Kingairloch House. This beautiful home sits in a commanding location with uninterrupted views of the magnificent mountains and glens of Kingairloch and the lapping shore of Loch a’ Choire and Loch Linnhe. Guests are welcome to explore the extensive gardens and the productive Victorian walled garden that encompass the house plus the surrounding 14,000 acres that is Kingairloch Estate.
imageWithContent_ID4559:
Through renovation and remodeling works carried out in the early 2000’s, the house is now a modern, tastefully decorated and furnished home. There is one luxurious en-suite bedroom, having glorious sea and mountainous views. Rooms start at £120/night and a two night stay is the minimum duration, however in certain circumstances, we may be able to take single night bookings. Please contact us directly if you wish to book a single night.

Additionally, if there is no availability displaying for your chosen dates, please get in touch as we do have other rooms that are not listed on our website.

We will take the first night as a deposit and additional nights are then payable 14 days prior to arrival.

cottageIcons_ID4559.similarPropertiesContent_ID4559: Sorry, no guests’ pets are allowed
Shared living room with open fire

bookingInfoBulletPoints1_ID4559: The room rate includes breakfast served in the dining room. There’s a choice of cereals, porridge and cooked breakfast. A favourite is Kinairloch scrambled eggs and local smoked salmon.
Lismore Bedroom: Super-King sized bed and bathroom has a shower.
bookingInfoBulletPoints2_ID4559:

bottomSectionReviewsContent_ID4559:
More Information about Kingairloch House

Dating back to the 18th century the Macleans of Kingairloch built the house as a replacement for their summer dwelling. During the winter months Airigh Shamhraidh was battered by storms off Loch Linnhe, so they sited the new main estate residence in a more sheltered location at the head of Loch a’Choire. (Visitors can visit the ruins of Airigh Shamhraid by walking the coast towards Glensanda). The house has been remodeled several times through changes of ownership, with the most notable taking place in 1903-1904 when the Derbyshire cotton mill magnate George Herbert Strutt enlarged the house to three stories with a side wing and turrets for use as their shooting lodge. In the mid 1960’s the house was drastically reduced in size, with the removal of the top floor and wing due to the emergence of dry rot and the ensuing increasing running costs of such a large property.
centerTextID4561:
The Boathouse

For private hire enquires, please get in touch.

activitiesOnKingairloch_ID4561.activitiesOnKingairlochContent_ID4561: Guided walks can be arranged to view and photograph wild red deer in their natural habitat…
We have 7km of circular tracks throughout Kingairloch. They are steep and challenging…
This most traditional Highland sporting activity has been enjoyed by people of all ages…

topSectionHeader_ID4563: Regular sightings of deer, pine martens, eagles and otters either from our properties or when out exploring the estate.
centerTextID4563:
Wildlife at Kingairloch

The Morvern peninsula is one of the most sparsely populated areas in the British Isles amounting to great landmasses that have hardly been touched by modern living. Often described as “the best kept secret in Scotland”, the peninsula is a wonderful place for people to discover the rich wildlife found on our doorstep. Kingairloch is home to a wide range of animals, birds and flora throughout the year, with the Winter months often having the most wildlife sightings.

We are extremely fortunate with the range of creatures at Kingairloch. For a bit of fun, during your holiday; have a go at spotting the Kingairloch “Magnificent Seven”.

You may also need a lot of patience and a pair of binoculars in some cases!
imageWithContent_ID4563:
Red Deer

Perhaps the most celebrated of all Scottish mammals, the red deer is also the largest and one of the most populous. In recent count figures, there was a population of approximately 500 on Kingairloch alone. As there are no fences on the peninsula separating estates, this figure fluctuates all year round. Stags and hinds live in separate herds for much of the year but come together rather vocally each Autumn in the breeding season, or rut. The glens come alive this time of year with the stags bellowing across at each other, a sound like no other! A stag may mate with up to twenty hinds in a given year. Calves are born in June.

When to see this species: Year Round

alternatingImageContentColImg_ID4563.imageWithContent_ID4563:
Red Deer

Perhaps the most celebrated of all Scottish mammals, the red deer is also the largest and one of the most populous. In recent count figures, there was a population of approximately 500 on Kingairloch alone. As there are no fences on the peninsula separating estates, this figure fluctuates all year round. Stags and hinds live in separate herds for much of the year but come together rather vocally each Autumn in the breeding season, or rut. The glens come alive this time of year with the stags bellowing across at each other, a sound like no other! A stag may mate with up to twenty hinds in a given year. Calves are born in June.

When to see this species: Year Round

Wild Goats

The feral goats are frequently spotted between Kingairloch and Kilmalieu, often on the cliff edges or eating seaweed on the shore. No two animals look the same, given the tremendous variety in coat colours and lengths. In some instances you may smell them before setting eyes on them! Mating takes place in late Autumn and kids are generally born into the chilly climes of January. Wild goats live together in herds, often in relatively large numbers.

When to see this species: Year Round

Otters

Spotting these shy creatures usually requires luck or patience, and definitely stillness and silence. Look out for signs (such as droppings, known as spraint, or webbed footprints in the sand) and keep a close eye on still water in the early morning or evening.

When to see this species: Year Round

Pine Marten

One of the hardest Scottish mammals to spot in the wild (primarily due to its nocturnal habits), this sleek woodland predator pops up around Kingairloch quite regularly. Due to their nocturnal activities, it may help to lay some bird food or eggs out for them.

When to see this species: Year Round

Golden Eagle

The golden eagle is a huge bird of prey, we are fortunate to have two breeding pairs nesting at Kingairloch. With its long broad wings and long tail, it has a different outline to the smaller buzzard. It likes to soar and glide on air currents, holding its wings in a shallow ‘V’. Eagles have traditional territories and nesting places, they are often seen in Glengalmadale and Ghardail as there is plenty open areas for them to hunt.

When to see this species: Year Round

Ptarmigan

The ptarmigan is a plump gamebird, slightly larger than a grey partridge. In summer, it is a mixture of grey, brown and black above with a white belly and wings. In winter, it becomes totally white except for its tail and eye-patch, which remain black. Ptarmigans feed on shoots, leaves, leaf buds, berries and insects. To spot ptarmigan, is a very rare occurrence, however if you are out walking on our highest mountains you may well be lucky enough as they tend to reside in our Arctic-like landscapes.

When to see this species: Autumn, Winter

Oystercatcher

Seen regularly in front of our loch-fronted cottages is the oystercatcher, often hunting for cockles and mussels. This is a fairly large body bird that is characterized with it’s orange-red bill, reddish-pink legs and black and white feathers. In flight, it shows a wide white wing-stripe, a black tail, and a white rump that extends as a ‘V’ between the wings.

When to see this species: Year Round

centerTextID4565: If you’re looking to get the most out of your stay at Kingairloch, why not book an activity during your stay and have a micro-adventure?

alternatingImageContentColImg_ID4565.imageWithContent_ID4565:
Guided Hill Walks

Guided walks can be arranged to view and photograph wild red deer in their natural habitat with the opportunity to glimpse wild goats, eagles, and a diverse range of flora. Not only is there the opportunity to see wildlife, but also the views from the hills are breathtaking and the silence is magical.

Mountain Biking and Footpath Routes

We have 7km of circular tracks throughout Kingairloch. They are steep and challenging, but it is worth it to see the scenery and wildlife. Guests and visitors are more than welcome to use these paths at all times throughout the year.

Hire our Finnish BBQ Hut

A unique experience to share with friends and family during your holiday.

Fishing

Sea Trout 1st July – 31st October
Brown Trout 15th March-30th September on rivers, lochan fishing is all year round

Trout Pond (near Home Farm)

Stocked with 1 – 6 pound brown trout
Fishing is free for guests staying on the estate. We operate a catch and release policy.

Clay Pigeon Shooting

This activity is currently unavailable.

Boat Trips and Kayaking Tours

Getting out on the water is one of the best ways to take in your surroundings when visiting the west coast of Scotland.

Red Deer Stalking at Kingairloch

This most traditional Highland sporting activity has been enjoyed by people of all ages and backgrounds at Kingairloch for over 150 years. Today we manage the wild red deer population through selective culling to conserve and promote a healthy stable population and protect the natural habitat at Kingairloch.

alternatingImageContentColImg_ID4757.imageWithContent_ID4757:
Accessible routes for exploring Kingairloch

We have 7km of circular tracks throughout Kingairloch. They are steep and challenging, but it is worth it to see the scenery and wildlife. Guests and visitors are more than welcome to use these paths at all times throughout the year. If you wish to hire bikes, Sunart Cycles are a local company, based nearby in Strontian that hire out mountain bikes, for more information visit their website.

Guided walks can be arranged to view and photograph wild red deer in their natural habitat with the opportunity to glimpse wild goats, eagles, and a diverse range of flora. Not only is there the opportunity to see wildlife, but also the views from the hills are breathtaking and the silence is magical.

Maximum of six people

For more information, please contact us.

We look forward to hearing from you.

The estate has three automatic autosporter clay traps that allow us to offer a variety of targets and disciplines, from clays suitable for beginners to challenging shots for experts – we can offer an exciting and varied approach to clay pigeon shooting. For this activity we use our estate 12 Bore shotguns.

centerTextID4782:
Seasons

Getting out on the water is one of the best ways to take in your surroundings when visiting the west coast of Scotland.

alternatingImageContentColImg_ID4782.imageWithContent_ID4782:
Kayaking Tours with Otter Adventures

Karl Bungey at Otter Adventures, a local firm based in Strontian are the epitome of kayaking adventures. He can put together some wonderful adventures for all abilities and the best part is that you can start them right at Kingairloch! We are part of a perfect outdoor playground that is the Morvern Peninsula and by not having to get in your car to start your adventure, it adds to your overall experience of our beautiful part of the United Kingdom. Bookings are made directly with Karl Bungey: hello@otter-adventures.co.uk

Book a private rib tour of our local waters

Coastal Connection have been taking visitors staying at Kingairloch on tours of our local waters for over 10 years. Their fast, covered and comfortable ribs means you can plan full day trips out on the water with them. From the comfort of the boats, you will have opportunities to see not only the rugged coastline but also a whole host of wildlife species including seals, sea eagles, dolphins and many other creatures. Bookings are made directly with Cameron or Struan Smith: info@coastal-connection.co.uk

activitiesOnKingairloch_ID4782.activitiesOnKingairlochContent_ID4782: Guided walks can be arranged to view and photograph wild red deer in their natural habitat…
We have 7km of circular tracks throughout Kingairloch. They are steep and challenging…
This most traditional Highland sporting activity has been enjoyed by people of all ages…

centerTextID4786:
Possibly the best red deer stalking in Scotland…..

This most traditional Highland sporting activity has been enjoyed by people of all ages and backgrounds at Kingairloch for over 150 years. Today we manage the wild red deer population through selective culling to conserve and promote a healthy stable population and protect the natural habitat at Kingairloch.  We do not shoot “trophy” stags, we select mature stags with often fairly poor-average heads. For our hind cull, we also have a strict management program.

Our highly experienced stalkers will accompany you on your private outing, and will offer expert advice and tuition. Our stalkers are able to guide people of any ability – from those never having handled a firearm before, to seasoned stalkers.

alternatingImageContentColImg_ID4786.imageWithContent_ID4786:
Seasons

Stags

The stag season runs from 1 July to the 20 October. Stalking is available in September and October.

Hinds

The hind season runs from the 21 October to the 15 February. Hind stalking available from October until mid December.

Availability

We are now fully booked for the 2020/21 season for both stags and hinds.

Accommodation

Fully catered accommodation is available in Kingairloch House, with menus tailored to guests’ specific needs. This includes a cooked breakfast with porridge, a packed lunch for the hill, a light lunch for any guests not going to the hill and an evening meal. What could be better than recounting the day sat round the grand dining table and unwinding by the large open fire in the lounge.

Additionally, guests can also choose to stay in our other self catering cottages which are located throughout the whole estate.

What to expect

Guests must wear stout lace-up footwear, warm tweed or camouflage clothing (which is non rustling), a peaked hat, gloves and a pair of binoculars are also worth having. Guests not staying at Kingairloch should come with a packed lunch. Walking sticks are provided.Guests are welcome to use the estate’s own rifle which is a .308 Tikka.

On the first morning guests will be taken to the target to familiarise with the rifle.

Stalking at Kingairloch require a very high level of fitness as you are out walking in tough terrain all day. Our deer are truly wild and live on open hillsides; a stalk will often involve walking up to 10 miles a day, starting at sea level and walking up our mountains which range between 500-600m, guests are then required to crawl in order to get into a good shootable position.
Secure storage is available for those bringing their own firearms. Click this link for a helpful guide on bringing your own firearm from overseas.

Booking

Please note that you must contact us first before booking accommodation for a stalking holiday as we need to check availability for the stalking first. When you have dates that you would like to enquire about, please get in touch info@kingairloch.co.uk

Testimonial

“I have never stalked in such dramatic landscapes, it took a while to get acclimatised to the demanding terrain. However, once we were in pursuit of our intended stag, I soon forgot the burning in my lungs and legs.”

Testimonial

“Having tried to find availability for four years, I finally managed to book a trip there. It did not disappoint! Can’t wait to return in the future.”

centerTextID4567:
Elopements at Kingairloch

Thank you for your interest in having your wedding at Kingairloch. We are a small venue suited for couples looking to start married life with their nearest and dearest friends and family in the romantic wilds of The Highlands. Weddings can take place all year round, you can choose to have just a weekend celebration or come and stay with us for seven nights and immerse yourselves in the rugged beauty of the estate.

alternatingImageContentColImg_ID4567.imageWithContent_ID4567:
The Ceremony

With the attendance of a registrar, couples can be married in Kingairloch House or should the weather be kind, in the surrounding gardens. For religious ceremonies, there is also the charming Kingairloch Church that is located right on the shore of Loch Linnhe. A third option is to have a humanist celebration where the ceremony itself can be conducted anywhere on the estate.

Your Elopement

The night before you say “I do” the bride and her wedding party are welcome to stay in Kingairloch House. Two rooms are available on a bed and breakfast basis, with the bridal suite having superior views of Loch Linnhe and Castle Stalker. Other members of the wedding celebrations can choose to stay in our charming self catering cottages that are located throughout the estate.

You have the option to have a pre-wedding evening celebratory meal in the delightful Boathouse or group together in one of our self catering properties.

Wedding ceremonies are to take place between 1pm and 5pm with the reception either being in the dining room of Kingairloch House, the ceilidh hall next to Kingairloch House or in The Boathouse. Carriages are to be before 11:30pm.

Tariffs

  • Bed and breakfast in Kingairloch House starts at £120 per night.

  • Kingairloch House is available for small ceremonies and receptions up to 12 people. The downstairs reception room, hall and dining room are included in the hire. Tariffs start at £500.

  • Adjacent to Kingairloch House is the magnificent Ceilidh Hall. With a sprung floor and walls adorned with red stags, this is a wonderful space for a celebration up to 50 guests. Tariffs start at £800.

  • A short walk from Kingairloch House is The Boathouse. At high tide, the water comes in underneath the building. This venue can take up to 30 guests. There is also a commercial kitchen available. Tariffs start at £800.

  • As we do not provide catering ourselves, we have a list of recommended suppliers below. Most have catered for celebrations in both Kingairloch House and The Boathouse and are aware of the facilities.

  • The hire period ceases in both venues at 11:30pm

  • All self-catering properties are available for weekly lets. Most are also available for short breaks from a Friday-Monday or Monday-Friday (tariffs available on website).

  • Special rates for single night bookings in our self catering properties are available on request.

Extras

  • Alcoholic drinks can be purchased through the estate.

  • Firework displays are permitted with prior arrangement before 10pm.

    Chinese lanterns are NOT allowed

  • Pets are welcome on the estate, however they are charged £24 each

Recommended Suppliers

Here is a list of suppliers that we have worked with in the past and we highly recommend, as they will make your dream elopement become a reality. Should you use suppliers that are not recommended by us, we will need to be informed who they are so we can communicate with them when required.

Due to our location, we would advise you of getting in touch with the key suppliers as soon as possible. Diaries fill up very quickly in the Highlands!

historyTextID4823:
Recent history of Kingairloch

Kingairloch has been in the care of the Yeoman and Larson family since the early 1980’s. The late John Yeoman was looking for a site for a coastal quarry and he looked at the neighbouring Glensanda, which was owned by the late Mrs Patricia Strutt who also owned Kingairloch. Mrs Strutt sold Glensanda to John Yeoman, owner of Foster Yeoman Ltd and he developed the coastal quarry until his untimely death in 1987.

Mrs Strutt decided that after a Strutt association of 98 years with Kingairloch, she would like the family company of Foster Yeoman Ltd to purchase Kingairloch, which was agreed in 1989. Mrs Strutt retained the management of Kingairloch until her death in 2001.

In 1996 the Larson family moved to Home Farm and Susan Larson (daughter of John and Angela Yeoman) started an agreed process of restoring the properties on Kingairloch. The premise behind the restoration projects was to achieve a time when Kingairloch could stand-alone and be financially viable. Foster Yeoman Ltd was sold in 2006 and Mrs Angela Yeoman and Mrs Susan Larson bought Kingairloch Estate to take it forward into the future. Although tourism plays a major role at Kingairloch, the estate has diversified into renewable energy, commercial and native forest whilst maintaining traditions as being a magnificent deer forest offering first class red deer stalking. Susan lives at Kingairloch House and her daughter Katrina manages the self-catering bookings and the online aspects of the estate.

Through forward thinking and diversification into different industries, it has become a wonderful place to holiday on the West Coast of Scotland. As you will see from the timeline below, we continually invest in the estate to safeguard it for our future generations.

A brief history of old Kingairloch

We believe in 1509, James IV granted the lands of Kingairloch to Ewen, son of Hector MacLean in exchange for the services of a well-equipped galley of 22 oars.

In the 18th century the Macleans of Kingairloch built Kingairloch House as a replacement for their summer dwelling.  The prior main house was along the coast on the shore of Loch Linnhe and was in the township of Airigh Shamhraidh. During the winter months it was continuously battered by storms, so they choose to site their new main estate residence in a more sheltered location at the head of Loch a’Choire. You are welcome to visit the ruins of Airigh Shamhraidh by walking the coast towards Glensanda. History has well reported the effect of The Highland Clearances and Kingairloch changed from having Township areas to one landholding.

Kingairloch House has been remodeled several times through changes of ownership, with the most notable taking place in 1903-1904 when the Derbyshire cotton mill magnate George Herbert Strutt enlarged the house to three stories with a side wing and turrets for use as their shooting lodge. In the mid 1960’s the house was drastically reduced in size due to the emergence of dry rot and the increasing running costs of such a large property. George Herbert Strutt’s son Arthur married a New Zealander, Patricia Kebbel who lived at Kingairloch until her passing in 2000.

Seaview Cottage, Ghardail Cottage, Pier Cottage, The Old Post Office and Elastic Cottage have all been renovated in a slightly different way but the central Stone construction is the same and we think was quarried from The Pier Quarry.

cottageHeoIcons_ID4654.cottageHeoIconsContent_ID4654: TV with DVD player in lounge.

mainContent4821:
Frequently Asked Questions

Q: Can you tell me the arrival and departure days for the cottages for seven night bookings?
A: Riverside Cottage, The Gate Lodge, The Old Post Office, Ghardail Cottage and Seaview Cottage let from a Friday. The Steadings, Curlew Cottage, Pier Cottage, Elastic Cottage and The Old School are from a Saturday.

Q: Do you allow short breaks?
A: Yes. Short breaks are available from either a Friday to Monday or a Monday to Friday in all of the properties (except The Steadings).

Q: What time can we arrive and when should we depart?
A: Arrival is after 4pm and departure is before 10am.

Q: Are dogs allowed in the properties?
A: Yes. Up to three dogs are allowed in each property, they are charged £24 each. They are only allowed in the kitchen and living area. Should your pet cause any damage, please notify us. There will be charges to rectify damage incurred.
Please bring your own bedding and bowls for your dogs.

Q: Can we purchase firewood?
A: Yes. We prepare bags of logs and kindling that can be purchased at any time. We also sell hottie heat logs.
Logs are £4/bag and kindling is £2. During the winter and early spring an initial supply of logs and kindling is provided. All properties have a fire, except for The Steadings.

Q: Can you provide travel cots and highchairs?
A: Yes.

Q: What is provided in the properties?
A: Bedrooms: All beds are made up with soft cotton sheets and towels are provided.
Bathrooms: Initial supply of toilet roll, hand towels, bath mats and nonslip bath mats
Kitchen: Salt and pepper. Washing up liquid, dishwasher tablets (for properties that have one), dish clothes, bin bags and tea towels

Q Are the kitchens well equipped?
A: We feel that they are extremely well equipped with various pots, pans, crockery, cutlery, glasses, knives and utensils. Should you find something missing in the cottage when you arrive, please speak to us as we usually have spares in our store cupboard.

Q: Will someone meet us when we arrive?
A: Due to the current climate with Covid-19, we will not be visiting you. In the properties you will find all the contact information you will require and very detailed instructions as to how the house works (TV instructions, heating instructions etc.)

Q: Where are the nearest shops?
– Fort William (1 hr – 1.5 hr drive including the Corran Ferry) there is a large Morrisions, Lidl and M&S.
– Strontian (45 minute drive, on our side of the ferry) there is a local post office, fuel pumps, and a larger Keystore.
– Lochaline (45 minute drive, on our side of the ferry) there is a local village shop

Q: Do any supermarkets deliver? 

Not at the moment.

Q: Can we purchase produce from the estate?
A: Yes. In the cottages will be information about what is available from the estate.

Q: Where is the nearest doctor/hospital.
A: Doctor Surgeries are in Lochaline and Acharcle. There is a hospital with A&E in Fort William.

Q: What are the midges like?
A: As Kingairloch is coastal; we are fortunate in often having a gentle breeze blowing all the time. This helps to keep the midges at bay. However, we do have them and they are generally about from June-September. To discourage them, in the evenings do not leave windows open with the lights on. The best repellant is Smidge. We would also recommend packing a midge hood.

Q: What is mobile signal like and do you have wifi?
A: We now have an EE mast on the estate, so we now have a very good 4G EE signal. Seaview Cottage, Ghardail Cottage, Curlew Cottage and The Steadings all have 4G wifi boxes that provide great internet service. We also have wifi available at The Boathouse, however this is a very slow speed.

Q: What can we do once we get to Kingairloch?
A: Lots! We have 7Km of footpath/cycle paths. Activities such as clay pigeon shooting, fishing and guided hill walks can be booked. For a memorable evening, you can hire our Finnish BBQ and toast marshmallows until your belly is full. Boat trips can also be booked for collection at the pier, we would recommend Coastal Connection. More information about activities is on our website.

Q: Do we need to pack anything in particular to make the most of our stay?
A: Here are a few top suggestions: good outdoor clothing and footwear, binoculars, a note pad, camera, good books and a map of the area. A road map is very useful, just incase mobile signal is down when you are out and about and you’re not sure of the best way back to the estate.
mainContent4819:
Privacy Policy

Kingairloch Estate LLP is committed to protecting your privacy.
We do not pass your personal information on to third parties.
All transactions that you initiate with Kingairloch Estate LLP on this web site are confidential.

The Law

Under the terms of the Data Protection Act 1998, we have a duty to protect any information we collect from you. It will not be disclosed to any other organization unless you give explicit permission, or there is a legal obligation to do so.
Additionally, The Privacy and Electronic Communications (EC Directive) (Amendment) Regulations 2011, has a requirement that websites that leave non-essential cookies on visitors’ devices have to inform the visitor what these cookies are. This website complies with this law by providing information on the cookies we use so that if you choose you can either modify your browser settings to manage cookies or leave the website.

What we do with your information

From time to time Kingairloch Estate LLP sends out newsletters detailing special events and news from the estate. This will only be sent to people who have chosen to opt in to receive the emails. At anytime you can unsubscribe from these emails.

Cookies

This web site also uses non-essential cookies so that we can serve you better, but all user data collected in this manner is anonymous. This site uses visitor tracking (Google Analytics) that will use cookies to track information about how visitors come to the website, which pages they visit, and other actions that visitors make whilst on the site. This data is then used in order to improve the user experience of our web site.
Non-essential Cookies also enhance our web site performance in a number of ways, personalising your experience on our site, making it more convenient for you.

Your Options

Should you wish to do so, you can refuse cookies by disabling them in your web browser’s settings. Most browsers are defaulted to accept and maintain cookies and you can set your browser to notify you when you receive a cookie, giving you the chance to decide whether to accept it or not. If you do not wish to disable cookies then you have the option to leave the website.

What is a Cookie?

Sadly, it is not something you can actually eat!
A cookie is a small amount of data that is sent in a text file to your computer browser from a website’s server and is then stored on your computer, but only IF your browser’s preferences are set by you to allow it. The only personal information a cookie can obtain is information a user supplies. A cookie cannot read data from your hard disk or read cookie files created by other sites.
mainContent4816:
Please read carefully. When you book your holiday with us you are signing a contract. Reservations are accepted subject to the following conditions.

Terms

All terms are per week (Saturday to Saturday or Friday to Friday) or for short stays. Except where stated, for the house/cottage as equipped and described. Bookings are from 4pm on day of arrival to 10am on day of departure (subject to unavoidable delays). Upon departure you are obliged to leave everything in a clean and tidy condition. Prices quoted include VAT at the Government set rate.

Covid-19 Special Circumstances- Bookings and Cancellation

Please read our Covid-19 statement for clarification on circumstances that relate to the virus.

We are now accepting bookings in all of our self catering properties, please note for multiple occupancy properties, we are only able to accept bookings from two households up to six people (children aged under 12 are not included in the head count).

For bookings from March onwards, dates will be confirmed with a 50% deposit being paid, the remaining balance will then be due 28 days prior to your arrival.

Should you wish to cancel an existing booking, in the first instance we would like to find alternative dates for you at Kingairloch. If this is not possible, we can provide a full refund. Please inform us as soon as possible should you wish to cancel your booking.

Contract

When you submit a booking via our online reservation system you will receive an automatically generated booking summary by email to the email address you provide in the booking form. This does not form a contract between us. A contract shall only arise when your booking is subsequently confirmed in writing via a letter of confirmation sent to you by email

Booking confirmation

Bookings are confirmed upon receipt of 50% of the accommodation rental. You will then become responsible for the total price.

Payment of Balance

The balance is due by you no later than 28 days before the holiday commencement date. For bookings made within 28 days of the start of your holiday you are required to pay the full price. In the event of this balance not being received within this period, we reserve the right to cancel the holiday without further notice and without any refund of deposit.

Availability

Should the house/cottage not be available due to circumstances beyond our control (for example fire, flooding or damage) we cannot guarantee to provide alternative accommodation, in which case all sums will be returned to you in full but you will have no claim against us.

Number in your party

Under no circumstances may more than the maximum number of persons, as stated, occupy the property. We reserve the right to cancel our contract, without a refund of sums paid, should this condition not be observed. We reserve the right to revoke any bookings from any parties which may, in our opinion (and at our sole discretion) be unsuitable for the property concerned. In this case, all sums paid will be refunded in full.

Pets

Pets may be accommodated in all our properties. Maximum number is three per property and only in reception rooms at £24/pet.

Damage

An inventory of the contents of each house will be checked at the beginning and end of each holiday period. Any articles found to be missing or broken will be paid for by you, as will any damage to the fabric (reasonable wear and tear acceptable).

Web Site

The information given on this web site is given in good faith. We reserve the right to make changes in the interests of improvements at any time.
